title: Srimad Bhagavatam | HG Chanchalapathi Dasa | SB 1.7.34 | 21-02-2016
speaker: HG Chanchalapathi Dasa

segments.text: Both Arjuna and Lord Shri Krishna are described here in an angry mood.
But Arjuna's eyes were like balls of red copper, whereas the eyes of the Lord were like lotuses.
This means that the angry mood of Arjuna and that of the Lord are not on the same level.
The Lord is Transcendence.
Please note, Transcendence with a capital T.
The Lord is Transcendence.
I hope it's the same there, yeah.
And thus he is absolute in any stage.
His anger is not like the anger of a conditioned living being.
Within the modes of qualitative material nature.
Because he is absolute, both his anger and pleasure are the same.
His anger is not exhibited in the three modes of material nature.
It is only a sign of his bent of mind towards the cause of his devotee.
Because that is his transcendental nature.
Therefore, even if he is...
He is angry, the object of anger is blessed.
He is unchanged in all circumstances.
Thus ends the Bhaktivedanta purport.
It's a very interesting part of the Bhagavatam.
Ashwatthama has been captured by Arjuna.
He is Rajva Bhadva.
He is being tightly bound by the ropes.
Ripum, he is his enemy.
Shibiraya Nishantam.
And it is Arjuna's intent that he should bring him to the Shibira military camp.
Praha, at that time, spoke.
Krishna spoke.
Praha, Arjuna.
And to Arjuna, Prakupitaha.
Praha, who is angry.
Bhagavan, Ambujekshanaha, Lord, who has lotus eyes, spoke.
Praha, because in the next verse we see Lord Krishna speaking.
So Bhagavan, Ambujekshanaha, Krishna, who has lotus eyes, spoke.
Prakupitaha, to angry Arjuna.
And in the purport, Srila Prabhupada has expanded the understanding and he has said that not only Arjuna was angry, even Krishna was angry about the whole thing.
If you see the next statement of Krishna, which you will see in your next class, he is telling Arjuna, kill him.
Obviously, you can't be telling Krishna to kill him.
You can't be telling Krishna to kill him in a very happy way.
Kill him.
So there is anger even in Krishna's voice.
So even Krishna is angry.
Arjuna is also angry.
Kill him.
So that's the kind of...
It's not a simple, normal conversation that's going on.
So it's full of anger.
And so, in the purport, we see how Srila Prabhupada is taking action.
And so, in the purport, we see how Srila Prabhupada is taking action.
Srila Prabhupada is taking this as an opportunity to explain that Arjuna's anger was that his eyes were red.
Krishna is also angry that his eyes are like lotus.
That is the difference.

Transcendental meaning, it is something not of this material
domain. In the material domain we are familiar with
Panchabhootas, right, earth, water, fire, all our bodies,
table, all of this is actually transformation of the Panchabhootas.
And the Panchabhootas are always undergoing transformation, that is
the nature of the Panchabhootas, and they are undergoing transformation
under the influence of Kala.
So in this material world we see material nature
constituting of the Panchabhootas under the influence of Kala
undergoing transformations.
But Krishna's position is not within the Panchabhootas,
not within the Kala, something that is beyond all of this.
He is beyond. Whether it is the Rig Veda, whether it is the Upanishad, whether it
is the Bhagavad Gita, all of them constantly repeat this
point.
Krishna's position is Tamasaha Parastaat. Tamasaha refers to the material world,
the Panchabhootas under the time. Tamasa also refers to ignorance,
also refers to darkness. This nature of the material world is dark,
and so Parastaat is beyond. Let's see how this material world is
beyond. Let's see how Krishna establishes this,
that his nature is very different and he is transcendental
in the Bhagavad Gita. They say, there are many places, but in a very
early part in the fourth chapter of the Gita,

vivasvate yogam proktavan aham proktavan.
avyaya yogam aham proktavan imam vivasvate
unto vivasvaan.

Because in the second chapter of the Gita, Krishna spoke.

Krishna concluded that about thus knowing oneself to be transcendental to material senses, mind and intelligence,
one should control the lower self by the higher self and thus by spiritual strength conquer this insatiable enemy known as lust.
That's how the third chapter ends.
And then this, how this evam buddhe param buddhva, by this transcendental knowledge, transcendental intelligence, how you should conquer.
So this knowledge concerning transcendence, yoga, this I spoke long ago to Vivasvan.
This is how Krishna is beginning the fourth chapter.

Just like, suppose I say, we are all here going to celebrate book distribution success, right?
So, suppose I tell you this story.
Three weeks back, I went to Delhi and

All these are big issues.
